{{Infobox dam | name = Ituango Dam | name_official = Pescadero-Ituango "José Tejada Sáenz" | image = Proceso de construcción del Proyecto Hidroeléctrico Ituango .jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Construction site in 2014 | image_alt = | location_map = Colombia | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|7|07|50.04|N|75|39|48.7|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = Colombia | location = [[Ituango]] | status =UC | construction_began = 2011 | opening = | demolished = | cost = US$3.8 billion | owner = | dam_type = Embankment, earth-fill clay core | dam_height = {{Convert|225|m|abbr=on}} | dam_height_thalweg = | dam_height_foundation= | dam_length = | dam_width_crest = | dam_width_base = | dam_volume = {{Convert|19000000|m3|abbr=on}} | dam_elevation_crest = | dam_crosses = [[Cauca River]] | spillway_count = | spillway_type = Service, gate controlled | spillway_capacity = {{Convert|22600|m3/s|abbr=on}} | res_name = | res_capacity_total = {{Convert|2720000000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | res_capacity_active ={{Convert|980000000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | res_capacity_inactive= | res_catchment = | res_surface = {{Convert|38|km2|abbr=on}} | res_elevation = | res_max_depth = | res_max_length ={{Convert|127|km|abbr=on}} | res_max_width = | plant_hydraulic_head = {{Convert|197|m|abbr=on}} (nominal) | res_tidal_range = | plant_operator = EPM Ituango | plant_commission = | plant_decommission = | plant_type = | plant_turbines = 8 x {{convert|307|MW|abbr=on}} [[Francis turbine|Francis type]] | plant_capacity = {{convert|2456|MW|abbr=on}} (planned) | plant_annual_gen = {{convert|9,200|GWh|abbr=on}} (firm) | website = http://www.hidroituango.com.co (Spanish) | extra = }} The '''Ituango Dam''', also referred to as the '''Pescadero-Ituango Dam''', is an [[embankment dam]] currently under construction on the [[Cauca River]] near [[Ituango]] in [[Antioquia Department]], [[Colombia]]. The primary purpose of the project is hydroelectric power generation and its power plant will have an [[installed capacity]] of {{convert|2456|MW}} when completed. Preliminary construction on the dam began in September 2011 and the power plant was expected to begin operations in late 2018, but will not after heavy rainfall and landslides in April/May 2018 blocked river's diversion tunnel, threatening a breach of the dam.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chadbourne Represented EPM Ituango in BOOMT Contract for the 2400 MW Hidroituango Project |url=http://www.chadbourne.com/Chadbourne-Represented-EPM-ITUANGO-in-BOOMT-CONTRACT-FOR-THE-2400-MW-HIDROITUANGO-PROJECT-04-28-2011/ |accessdate=9 July 2011 |date=28 April 2011}}</ref> When completed, it will be the largest power station in Colombia.<ref>{{cite web |title=China, South Korea companies in race for Colombia hydropower deal |url=http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/economy/8005-china-south-korea-companies-in-race-for-colombia-hydropower-deal-.html |publisher=Colombia Reports |accessdate=9 July 2011|date=3 February 2010}}</ref>
==Background== The dam's feasibility study was completed in 1983 but the project was shelved in the 1990s due to an economic crisis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Colombia hydro utility to build 2,688-MW Pescadero Ituango |url=http://www.hydroworld.com/index/display/article-display/99999/articles/hrhrw/News/Colombia_hydro_utility_to_build_2688-MW_Pescadero_Ituango.html |publisher=HydroWorld|accessdate=9 July 2011 |date=7 December 2011}}</ref> The final designs for the project were finished in 2008 and on 8 July 2011, the project management contract was awarded. Preliminary construction (surveying, roads, bridges, diversion tunnels) began in September 2011 and it is expected to be complete in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |title=Construction preparation begins for 2,400-MW Ituango in Colombia |url=http://www.hydroworld.com/index/display/article-display.articles.hrhrw.hydroindustrynews.newdevelopment.2011.09.construction-preparation-begins-for-2400-mw-ituango-in-colombia.QP129867.dcmp=rss.page=1.html |publisher=Hydro World |accessdate=29 March 2012|date=22 September 2011}}</ref> Main works will begin thereafter and the power plant is expected to being commissioning in 2018. Development of the project is being proposed by EPM Ituango, a consortium of Empresas Publicas de Medellin (EPM) and the Antioquia government. The total cost is expected to be US$2.8 billion.<ref>{{cite web |title=Evolution of Expansion Plans |url=http://www.epm.com.co/docs-bid/energia/proyectos-energia-EN.pdf |publisher=EPM |accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Consortium wins US66 million contract for Ituango hydro project build in Colombia |url=http://www.hydroworld.com/index/display/article-display/7635287117/articles/hrhrw/hydroindustrynews/newdevelopment/2011/07/consortium-wins_us66.html |publisher=HydroWorld |accessdate=9 July 2011|date=8 July 2011}}</ref>
==Design== The dam will be a {{Convert|225|m|adj=on}} tall earth-fill embankment type with a clay core. The volume of the dam will be {{Convert|19|e6m3|}}. Its [[reservoir]] will have a capacity of {{Convert|2720|e6m3|acre.ft|adj=on}} of which {{Convert|980|e6m3|acre.ft||adj=on}} will be active (or "useful") capacity. The reservoir will be {{Convert|127|km}} long and cover an area of {{Convert|38|km2|}}. To maintain reservoir levels, the dam will have a [[spillway]] controlled by four [[radial gate]]s with a design flow of {{Convert|22600|m3/s}}. The dam's power plant will have a nominal [[hydraulic head]] of {{Convert|197|m}} and contain eight {{convert|307|MW}} [[Francis turbine]]-generators.<ref>{{cite web |title=Datos Técnicos |url=http://www.hidroituango.com.co/hidroituango/index.php/es/el-proyecto/datos-tecnicos |publisher=Hidroeléctrica Ituango |accessdate=9 July 2011 |language=Spanish }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Diversion tunnel blockage == Three tunnels were constructed to divert the Cauca River around the construction site. Two were eventually sealed during construction, leaving a third to divert the river.<ref>{{cite web |title=Reabren 3 túneles para evacuar aguas embalsadas en Hidroituango |url=http://caracol.com.co/emisora/2018/05/08/medellin/1525779198_834090.html |publisher=Caracol Radio |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=8 May 2018}}</ref> Between 28 April and 7 May 2018, three landslides blocked the tunnel, leading the reservoir to fill.<ref>{{cite web |title= Nuevo derrumbe en proyecto Hidroituango |url=http://www.elcolombiano.com/antioquia/hidroituango-presento-un-nuevo-derrumbe-XC8631321 |publisher=El Colombiano |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=30 April 2018}}</ref> Engineers attempted to open the two closed tunnels with explosives but were unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web |title=Reabren 3 túneles para evacuar aguas embalsadas en Hidroituango |url=http://caracol.com.co/emisora/2018/05/08/medellin/1525779198_834090.html |publisher=Caracol Radio |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=8 May 2018}}</ref> On 10 May, when the reservoir reached the power station intake, engineers began releasing water through the unfinished power house to prevent a breach of the dam.<ref>{{cite web |title=Se agrava situación en Hidroituango, deberán inundar casa de máquinas |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/medellin/hidroituango-inundara-casa-de-maquinas-por-represamiento-de-agua-215834 |publisher=El Tiempo |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=10 May 2018}}</ref> On 12 May one of the previous sealed tunnels naturally reopened, which suddenly increased downstream flows by three times the average.<ref>{{cite web |title=Así fue el destaponamiento del túnel de Hidroituango |url=http://www.elcolombiano.com/antioquia/hidroituango-destaponamiento-del-tunel-IN8690291 |publisher=El Colombiano |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=12 May 2018}}</ref> This promoted evacuations downstream, eventually totaling around 25,000.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hidroituango: cuatro puentes afectados deja incremento del nivel de aguas del río Cauca |url=http://www.wradio.com.co/noticias/actualidad/hidroituango-cuatro-puentes-afectados-deja-incremento-del-nivel-de-aguas-del-rio-cauca/20180513/nota/3749184.aspx |publisher=W Radio |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=13 May 2018}}</ref>
On May 16 silt build-up in a portion of the power house, the only means to drain the reservoir, led to water escaping into a transit gallery used by construction vehicles. The water eventually poured onto the downstream face of the dam, eroding the roadway and a portion of the [[riprap]].<ref>{{cite web |title="Hubo una obstrucción en la casa de máquinas": EPM sobre emergencia en Hidroituango |url=https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/nacional/hubo-una-obstruccion-en-la-casa-de-maquinas-epm-sobre-emergencia-en-hidroituango-articulo-788913 |publisher=El Espectador |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=16 May 2018}}</ref> Subsequently, EPM announced a risk of collapse existed and workers continued to fill the dam to its design height in hopes the spillway could be used to prevent an over-topping of the dam.<ref>{{cite web |title=‘Existe la posibilidad de que se rompa la presa de Hidroituango’: gerente de EPM |url=https://www.elespectador.com/economia/existe-la-posibilidad-de-que-se-rompa-la-presa-de-hidrotuango-presidente-de-epm-articulo-789028 |publisher=El Espectador |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=17 May 2018}}</ref> Heavy rainfall was expected in the Cauca River basin through the end of May.<ref>{{cite web|title=Colombia Ituango Dam Emergency 22 May 2018|url=https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/ECDM_20180522_Colombia_Dam_Floods.pdf|website=Relief Web|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
The financial loss that has emanated from this is large and the proximate cause is, without a doubt, Natural Perils given the rainfall.
==Ecological impact== The dam construction has severe ecological consequences, and there are displaced families, environmentalists, youth groups and concerned locals that oppose the project.<ref name="mond_Colo">{{Cite web | title = Colombia’s other war | author = Naomi Cohen | work = Le Monde diplomatique | date = 16 January 2017 | accessdate = 28 January 2017 | url = http://mondediplo.com/outsidein/colombia-s-other-war }}</ref>

{{Use Indian English|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox project | abbreviation = JNNSM | hi = | logo = | image = | caption = | mission_statement = Achieve 100 GW solar capacity by 2022 | type = Solar energy mission | country = India | primeminister = [[Manmohan Singh]] (2010-14)
[[Narendra Modi]] (2014-present) | ministry = [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] | key_people = | launched = {{start date and age|2010|1|11|df=y}} | launch_place = | closed = ''{{End date and age|2022||df=y}}'' | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.mnre.gov.in/solar-mission/jnnsm/introduction-2/}} | current_status = Active }} The '''Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission''', also known as the '''National Solar Mission''', is an initiative of the [[Government of India]] and State Governments to promote solar power. The mission is one of the several initiatives that are part of the National Action Plan on Climate Change.[http://www.c2es.org/international/country-policies/india-climate-plan-summary/06-2008 India's National Action Plan on Climate Change - Highlights] The program was inaugurated[http://www.hindu.com/2010/01/12/stories/2010011260911100.htm JNNSM Inauguration] by former [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh]] on 11 January 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.mnre.gov.in/solar-mission/jnnsm/introduction-2/ |title=Ministry of New and Renewable Energy - Scheme / Documents |publisher=Mnre.gov.in |date= |accessdate=2016-09-14}} with a target of 20GW by 2022 which was later increased to 100 GW by the [[Modi ministry|Narendra Modi government]] in the [[2015 Union budget of India]].{{Cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=122566|title=Revision of cumulative targets under National Solar Mission from 20,000 MW by 2021-22 to 1,00,000 MW|last=|first=|date=|website=pib.nic.in|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-27}} India increased its solar power generation capacity by nearly 5 times from 2,650 MW on 26 May 2014{{cite web|title=India's solar capacity to cross 20GW in next 15 months: Piyush Goyal|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/economy/2242515-2242515.html|website=Money Control|accessdate=18 March 2017}} to 12,288.83 MW on 31 March 2017. The country added 5,525.98 MW in 2016-17, the highest of any year. ==Objective== [[File:Solar Resource Map of India.png|thumb|[[Solar irradiance|Solar Resource]] Map of India]] The objective of the National Solar Mission is to establish [[India]] as a global leader in [[solar energy]], by creating the policy conditions for its diffusion across the country as quickly as possible. Under the original plan, the Government aimed to achieve a total installed solar capacity of 20 GW by 2022. This was proposed to be achieved in three phase. The first phase comprised the period from 2010 to 2013, the first year of the 12th five-year plan. The second phase extended up to 2017, while the third phase would have been the 13th five-year plan (2017–22). Targets were set as 1.4 GW in the first phase, 11-15 GW by the end of the second phase and 22 GW by the end of the third phase in 2022.{{cite web|title=Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission Phase II – Policy Document|url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/UserFiles/draft-jnnsmpd-2.pdf|website=Ministry of New & Renewable Energy|accessdate=27 March 2017|date=December 2012}} The Government revised the target from 20 GW to 100 GW on 1 July 2015. To reach 100 GW by 2022, the yearly targets from 2015-16 onwards were also revised upwards.{{cite web|last1=Kapoor|first1=Tarun|title=Scaling up of Grid Connected Solar Power Projects|url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/grid-solar/100000MW-Grid-Connected-Solar-Power-Projects-by-2021-22.pdf|website=Ministry of New and Renewable Energy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226140523/http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/grid-solar/100000MW-Grid-Connected-Solar-Power-Projects-by-2021-22.pdf|archivedate=February 26, 2017|date=1 July 2015}} India had an installed solar capacity of 161 MW on 31 March 2010, about 2 and half months after the mission was launched on 11 January. By 31 March 2015, three months before the targets were revised, India had achieved an installed solar capacity of 3,744 MW. ===Year-wise targets=== To meet the scaled up target of 100,000 MW, MNRE has proposed to achieve it through 60 GW of large and medium scale solar projects, and 40 GW through rooftop solar projects. {| class="wikitable" |+ Year-wise Targets (in MW) ! Category ! 2015-16 ! 2016-17 ! 2017-18 ! 2018-19 ! 2019-20 ! 2020-21 ! 2021-22 ! Total |- ! Rooftop Solar | 200 || 4,800 || 5,000 || 6,000 || 7,000 || 8,000 || 9,000 || 40,000 |- ! Ground Mounted Solar projects | 1,800 | 7,200 | 10,000 | 10,000 | 10,000 | 9,500 | 8,500 | 57,000 |- ! Total | 2,000 || 12,000 || 15,000 || 16,000 || 17,000 || 17,500 || 17,500 || 97,000 |} ===Growth of utilities installed solar capacity=== The following table records the growth of the utilities installed solar capacity in India for every year of the National Solar Mission. All capacities are as on 31 March of the listed year. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Installed capacity !Annual growth (MW) !Annual growth (%) |- |2010 |161 MW |{{N/A}} |{{N/A}} |- |2011 |461 MW |300 MW |186.34 % |- |2012 |1,205 MW |744 MW |161.39 % |- |2013 |2,319 MW |1,114 MW |92.45 % |- |2014 |2,632 MW{{cite web|title=ALL INDIA INSTALLED CAPACITY (IN MW) OF POWER STATIONS (As on 31.03.2014) (UTILITIES)|url=http://cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/installedcapacity/2014/installed_capacity-03.pdf|website=CEA|accessdate=27 March 2017}} |313 MW |13.50 % |- |2015 |3,744 MW{{cite web|title= ALL INDIA INSTALLED CAPACITY (IN MW) OF POWER STATIONS LOCATED IN THE REGIONS OF MAIN LAND AND ISLANDS (As on 31.03.2015) (UTILITIES)|url=http://cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/installedcapacity/2015/installed_capacity-03.pdf|website=CEA|accessdate=27 March 2017}} |1,112 MW |42.25 % |- |2016 |6,762.85 MW{{cite web|title= ALL INDIA INSTALLED CAPACITY (IN MW) OF POWER STATIONS (As on 31.03.2016) (UTILITIES)|url=http://cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/installedcapacity/2016/installed_capacity-03.pdf|website=CEA|accessdate=27 March 2017}} |3,018.85 MW |80.63% |- |2017 |12,288.83 MW{{cite web|title=India's solar energy capacity expanded by record 5,525 MW - The Economic Times|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/indias-solar-energy-capacity-expanded-by-record-5525-mw/articleshow/58037873.cms|website=The Economic Times|accessdate=6 April 2017}} |5,525.98 MW |81.71% |- |2018 |21,651.48 MW{{cite web|title= ALL INDIA INSTALLED CAPACITY (IN MW) OF POWER STATIONS (As on 31.03.2018) (UTILITIES)|url=http://cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/installedcapacity/2018/installed_capacity-03.pdf|website=CEA|accessdate=19 May 2018}} |9,362.65 MW |76.19% |- |2019 | | | |- |2020 | | | |- |2021 | | | |- |2022 | | | |} ==Phase 1 (2010-13)== The first phase of this mission aims to commission 1000 MW of grid-connected [[solar power]] projects by 2013. The implementation of this phase is in hands of a subsidiary of [[National Thermal Power Corporation]], the largest power producer in India. The subsidiary, NTPC Vidyut Vyapar Nigam Ltd (NVVN),[http://nvvn.co.in/ NVVN] laid out guidelines for selection of developers for commissioning grid connected solar power projects in India. See [http://www.mnre.gov.in/solar%20energy%20conclave%202010/solar-energy-conclave-2010-2.pdf JNNSM Phase 1 Guidelines]. While NVVN is the public face of this phase, several other departments and ministries will play a significant role in formulating guidelines. NVVN will sign [[power purchase agreements]] with the developers. Since NVVN is not a [[Public utility|utility]], it will sell purchased power to different state utilities via separate agreements. === Technologies === For Phase 1 projects, NVVN started with a proposal for 50:50 allocation towards [[Photovoltaic system|solar PV]] and [[Solar thermal energy|solar thermal]]. The latter is quite ambitious given India has no operational solar thermal projects and less than 10MW of solar PV projects. While growing at a rapid pace lately, solar thermal technologies are still evolving globally. The first batch of projects allotted for Phase 1 included 150MW of Solar PV and 500MW of Solar Thermal. NVVN issued Request for Selection document outlining criteria for selection of projects under the Phase 1. See [http://www.nvvn.co.in/RFS%20Document%20-%20Solar%20Thermal.pdf Solar Thermal RFS], [http://www.nvvn.co.in/RFS%20Document%20-%20Solar%20PV.pdf Solar PV RfS] A growing solar PV industry in India is hoping to take off by supplying equipment to power project developers. Well known equipment manufacturers started increasing their presence in India and may give competition to local Indian manufacturers. Due to generally high temperatures in India, [[Polycrystalline silicon|crystalline silicon]]-based products are not the most ideal ones. [[Thin film solar cell|Thin film]] technologies like [[amorphous silicon]], [[Copper indium gallium selenide#CIGS photovoltaic cells|CIGS]] and [[Cadmium telluride|CdTe]] could be more suitable for higher temperature situations. Solar thermal technology providers barely have a foothold in India. A few technology providers like [[Abengoa]] [http://www.abengoasolar.com/corp/web/en/about_us/international_presence/index.html abengoa] have some Indian presence in anticipation of demand from this mission. === NVVN Solar PV allotment process for Phase 1 === NVVN issued Request for Selection notice for allotment of capacity to Independent Power Producers (IPPs). See [http://www.nvvn.co.in/RFS%20Document%20-%20Solar%20PV.pdf NVVN Solar PV RfS]. 150MWs of Solar PV and 470MW of Solar Thermal were up for allotment under the first batch of Phase 1 projects. Project size per IPP was fixed at 5MW for Solar PV and 100MW for Solar Thermal projects. To avoid allocating entire capacity to a select few corporate, guidelines required no two projects to have the same parent company or common shareholders. In case of over subscription, a reverse bidding process was to be used to select the final IPPs based on lowest tariff they offer. Several hundred IPPs responded to this RfS. The approach for reverse bidding and methodology to calculate the discount to be offered was presented by Shri Shakti Alternative Energy Ltd through a webinar on 19 October 2010 on the eve of the reverse bidding by NVVN [http://www.ssael.co.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67&Itemid=82 Download presentation on Reverse Bidding by NVVN - What to Expect].[http://www.ssael.co.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67&Itemid=82 Webinar On Reverse Bidding Strategy] The quantum of discount would depend on project site location (i.e. solar radiation), technology used, simulated energy generation, capital cost and interest cost. Multivariate analysis was carried out using key variables like capital cost, interest and the capacity utilization factor (i.e. CUF which is actual generation of the plant and depends on the location (radiation) and technology used)to calculate the levelized tariff for a target equity IRR based on which the discount to be offered can be determined. The final 30 solar PV projects{{cite web|title=NVVN Phase 1 Batch 1 Solar PV Projects|url=http://www.nvvn.co.in/Selected%20Projects%20List.pdf}} selected had bids between INR 10.95 to INR 12.75. The Solar Thermal projects selected had bids between INR 10.24 to INR 12.24. PPAs were signed with IPPs in early January. ==2014-present== In December 2014, the Government of India introduced a scheme to establish at least 25 solar parks and [[Ultra Mega Solar Power Projects]] to add over 20 GW of installed solar power capacity. The Central Government provides financial support for the construction of these solar projects.{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=121060|title=Scheme for Development of Ultra Mega Solar Parks|date=|publisher=Pib.nic.in|accessdate=2016-07-24}} As of December 2016, the Central Government has provided in-principle approval to set up 34 solar parks across 21 states.{{Cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/companies/large-scale-solar-projectsindia-atmercypoor-infra-926899.html|title=Large-scale solar projects in India at the mercy of poor infra|website=www.moneycontrol.com|access-date=2017-03-20}} Each power project has a minimum capacity of 500 MW.{{cite web|author=Smiti Mittal|url=http://cleantechnica.com/2014/09/15/india-considers-adding-20-gw-capacity-ultra-mega-solar-power-projects/ |title=India Considers Adding 20 GW Capacity Through Ultra Mega Solar Power Projects |publisher=Cleantechnica.com |date=2014-09-15 |accessdate=2016-07-24}} == Domestic content complaint == Guidelines for the solar mission mandated cells and modules for solar PV projects based on crystalline silicon to be manufactured in India. That accounts to over 60% of total system costs. For solar thermal, guidelines mandated 30% project to have domestic content. A vigorous controversy emerged between power project developers and solar PV equipment manufacturers. The former camp prefers to source modules by accessing highly competitive global market to attain flexible pricing, better quality, predictable delivery and use of latest technologies.[Kevin Roebuck, [https://books.google.com/books?id=UEYPBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA87&lpg=PA87&dq=The+former+camp+prefers+to+source+modules+by+accessing+highly+competitive+global+market+to+attain+flexible+pricing,+better+quality,+predictable+delivery+and+use+of+latest+technologies.&source=bl&ots=BJRKWD5PNY&sig=0xCbmAeg-_d-nHEXTvp18nf_W54&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r2JAVYGbIYnuoASL-4DYDA&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=The%20former%20camp%20prefers%20to%20source%20modules%20by%20accessing%20highly%20competitive%20global%20market%20to%20attain%20flexible%20pricing%2C%20better%20quality%2C%20predictable%20delivery%20and%20use%20of%20latest%20technologies.&f=false Solar PPA: High-impact Strategies - What You Need to Know: Definitions, Adoptions, Impact, Benefits, Maturity, Vendors], pg. 87] The latter camp prefers a controlled/planned environment to force developers to purchase modules from a small, albeit growing, group of module manufacturers in India.[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-05-12/edit-page/28285093_1_solar-energy-renewable-energy-modules-from-other-countries domesticPro] Manufacturers want to avoid competition with global players and are lobbying the government to incentivise growth of local industry{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}}. Market responded to domestic content requirement by choosing to procure thin film modules from well established international players. A significant number of announced project completions are using modules from outside India.{{cite web|title=First Solar to supply modules for an Indian Solar PV developer|url=http://investor.firstsolar.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=201491&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1505898&highlight=}}{{cite news|title=Trina supplying modules for an Indian Solar PV plant|url=http://powerwatchindia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=240:trina-solar-completes-5-mw-power-project-in-india&catid=2:news&Itemid=3}} [[US Trade Representative]] has filed a complaint at [[World Trade Organization]] challenging India’s domestic content requirements in Phase II of this Mission, citing discrimination against US exports and that industry in US which has invested hugely will be at loss. US insists that such restrictions are prohibited by WTO. India however claims that it is only an attempt to grow local potential and to ensure self sustenance and reduce dependence{{cite web|title=US challenges India’s Domestic Rules in National Solar Mission|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/02/us-challenges-indias-domestic-rules-in-national-solar-mission/|work=IANS|publisher=news.biharprabha.com|accessdate=11 February 2014}} ==See also== * [[Solar power in India]] * [[Electricity sector in India]] * [[Solar Energy Corporation of India]] * [[Renewable energy in India]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.mnre.gov.in Ministry of New and Renewable Energy website] * [http://seci.gov.in/upload/files/what_new/news/55684f9a98324CommissioningStatusMNREandwebsite.pdf List of Projects Commissioned under JNNSM Phase II Batch I] {{SPIN}} {{Government Schemes in India}} [[Category:Renewable energy policy]] [[Category:Solar power in India]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials to Jawaharlal Nehru]] [[Category:Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] [[Category:Manmohan Singh administration]] [[Category:Modi administration]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Liberty Puzzles, LLC | logo = Liberty Puzzles logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | genre = | foundation = [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]], [[Colorado]] (2005) | founder = Christopher Wirth, Jeffrey Eldridge | location_city = [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]], [[Colorado]] | location_country = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | industry = | products = Wooden [[jigsaw puzzle]]s | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.libertypuzzles.com}} US & Worldwide website
| footnotes = | intl = }} '''Liberty Puzzles''' is a manufacturer of classic style wooden [[jigsaw puzzles]] based in [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]], Colorado. It was founded in 2005 by Christopher Wirth and his business partner Jeffrey Eldridge, after Wirth’s family inherited several hand-cut wooden puzzles from the 1930s.<ref>{{cite book | last = Cutrofello | first = Tom | title = Pieces of Art: Cutting Edge Jigsaws | publisher = Games Magazine | year = 2010}}</ref> Surprised by the value of hand-cut wooden jigsaw puzzles (which can sell for more than $1,000 each), Wirth decided to start a business using modern cutting technologies, with a goal of producing puzzles in the $100 range.<ref>Peterson, Eric (Nov. 2008). “Liberty Puzzles: Colorado Cool Stuff.” Entrepreneur Magazine. http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/189501399.html</ref> Wirth is the son of former Colorado senator [[Tim Wirth]].
Liberty Puzzles is the largest or second largest wooden jigsaw puzzle manufacturer in America as of 2011. The company offers over 600 different puzzle images, with an emphasis on fine art, vintage prints and Asian art. They continuously expand their range, increasingly with local contemporary artists.
The puzzles are made in [[Boulder, Colorado]] with archival paper and inks adhered to quarter-inch maple plywood cut with computer-controlled laser cutters. The puzzle designs are modeled after the puzzles popular in the early-twentieth century. Jigsaw puzzle historian Bob Armstrong notes: "the style of cutting and figure pieces emulates the Falls puzzles from the 1930s".<ref>{{cite web | last = Armstrong | first = Bob | title = Puzzles Cut By Today's Makers | url = http://www.oldpuzzles.com}}</ref> Liberty's puzzles include a relatively large number of whimsy pieces (pieces shaped recognizably, for example, as storks or swans), "as much as 20 percent of the pieces... [in some puzzles]".<ref>{{cite book | last = Cutrofello | first = Tom |title = Pieces of Art: Cutting Edge Jigsaws | publisher = Games Magazine | year = 2010}}</ref> Most Liberty Puzzles include the company's signature whimsy piece in the shape of an eagle.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://libertypuzzles.com Liberty Puzzles Official Website] *Liberty Puzzles- Old meets new- Laser cut wood puzzles (Photos, 2008). https://makezine.com/2008/02/19/liberty-puzzles-old-meets/ *Peacock, Charles. “Wooden Whimsy Jigsaw Puzzles.” http://www.articleinsider.com/games-and-recreation/puzzles/wooden-whimsy-jigsaw-puzzles *McAdams, Daniel. “History of Jigsaw Puzzles.” http://www.jigsaw-puzzle.org/jigsaw-puzzle-history.html *Sarah Protzman Howlett (December 2014). "A Piece of Boulder: A Boulder puzzle maker brings his unique jigsaws to the Pearl Street Mall." 5280. http://www.5280.com/magazine/2014/11/piece-boulder
[[Category:Toy companies of the United States]] [[Category:Wooden toys]] [[Category:Puzzle designers]] [[Category:Companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Companies based in Boulder, Colorado]] [[Category:Jigsaw puzzle manufacturers]]

{{mergeto | Lifting gas|date=February 2018}}
'''Lighter than air''' refers to materials (usually [[gas]]es) that are [[buoyancy|buoyant]] in [[air]] because they have [[density|average densities]] lower than [[density of air|that of air]]. Dry air has a density of about 1.29 [[g/L]] (gram per liter) at [[standard conditions for temperature and pressure]] (STP) and an average molecular mass of 28.97 [[Molar mass|g/mol]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/molecular-mass-air-d_679.html|title=Air - Molecular Weight|website=www.engineeringtoolbox.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref>
Some of these gases are used as [[lifting gas]]es in [[aerostat|lighter-than-air aircraft]], which include [[balloon (aircraft)|free balloons]], [[moored balloon]]s, and [[airships]]. Heavier-than-air [[aircraft]] include [[airplane]]s, gliders and helicopters.
==Usage as lifting gas== {{main|Lifting gas}}
=== Hot air === [[Hot air balloon|Hot air]] is frequently used in recreational ballooning. Hot air is lighter than air at ambient temperature, to a degree which can be approximated using the [[ideal gas law]].
=== Neon === [[Neon]] (density 0.900 g/L at STP, average atomic mass 20.17g/mol) is lighter than air and will lift a balloon. However, it is relatively rare on Earth, expensive, and is among the heavier of the lifting gases.
=== Water vapor === [[Water vapor]] (density 0.804 g/L at STP, average molecular mass 18.015 g/mol) is lighter than air, and has successfully been used as a lifting gas. It is generally impractical due to high boiling point and condensation.
===Ammonia=== [[Ammonia]] (density 0.769 g/L at STP, average molecular mass 17.03 g/mol) has sometimes been used to fill [[weather balloon]]s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/gas-density-d_158.html|title=Gases - Density|website=www.engineeringtoolbox.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> Due to its relatively high boiling point (compared to helium and hydrogen), ammonia could potentially be refrigerated and liquified aboard an airship to reduce lift and add ballast (and returned to a gas to add lift and reduce ballast).
===Methane=== [[Methane]] (density 0.716 g/L at STP, average molecular mass 16.04 g/mol) is the chief component of [[natural gas]] and is sometimes used as a lift gas when hydrogen and helium are not available.<ref name=":0" /> It has the advantage of not leaking through balloon walls as rapidly as the small-moleculed hydrogen and helium. Many lighter-than-air balloons are made of aluminized plastic that limits such leakage; hydrogen and helium leak rapidly through latex balloons.
===Hydrogen and helium=== [[Hydrogen]] (density 0.090 g/L at STP, average molecular mass 2.016 g/mol) and [[helium]] (density 0.179 g/L at STP, average molecular mass 4.003 g/mol) are the most commonly used lift gases. Although helium is twice as heavy as (diatomic) hydrogen, they are both much lighter than air that this difference only results in hydrogen having 8% more [[buoyancy]] than helium.
In a practical [[Airship|dirigible]] design, the difference is significant, making a 50% difference in the fuel-carrying capacity of the dirigible and hence increasing its range significantly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,786149-2,00.html|title=AERONAUTICS: Helium vs. Hydrogen|last=|first=|date=1924-03-10|website=|publisher=TIME|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209024932/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,786149-2,00.html|archive-date=February 9, 2011|dead-url=|accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> However, hydrogen is extremely flammable and its use as a lifting gas in dirigibles has decreased since the [[Hindenburg disaster]]. Helium is safer as a lifting gas because it is inert and does not undergo combustion.
== Others ==
=== Nitrogen === [[Nitrogen]] gas (density 1.251 g/L at STP, average atomic mass 28.00 g/mol) is about 3% lighter than air, insufficient for common use as a lifting gas.<ref name=":0" />
=== Solids === In 2002, [[aerogel]] held the [[Guinness World Record]] for the least dense (lightest) solid.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2002/TECH/space/05/09/record.gel/index.html|title=CNN.com - NASA's 'frozen smoke' named lightest solid - May 9, 2002|last=CNN|first=Richard Stenger|website=edition.cnn.com|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> Aerogel is mostly air because its structure is like that of a highly vacuous [[sponge]]. The lightness and low [[density]] is due primarily to the large proportion of air within the solid and not the [[silicon]] construction materials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/topics/technology/features/aerogels.html|title=Aerogels: Thinner, Lighter, Stronger|last=Administrator|first=NASA Content|date=2015-04-15|work=NASA|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en}}</ref> Taking advantage of this, [[SEAgel]], in the same family as aerogel but made from [[agar]], can be filled with helium gas to create a solid which floats when placed in an open top container filled with a dense gas.<ref name="Discovery Channel">{{Citation|last=Grommo|title=SEAgel Aerogel lighter than air solid. Not a UFO|date=2008-06-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HoCAxS4vqwQ|accessdate=2018-01-16}}</ref>
In 2012, discovery of [[aerographite]] was announced, breaking the record for the least dense material at only 0.2 mg/cm<sup>3</sup> (0.2 kg/m<sup>3</sup>).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2012-07-carbon-nanotube-struructure-aerographite-lightest.html |title=New carbon nanotube struructure aerographite is lightest material champ |doi=10.1002/adma.201200491 |publisher=[[Phys.org]] |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/technik/aerographit-leichtestes-material-der-welt-entwickelt-a-843819.html |title=Aerographit: Leichtestes Material der Welt entwickelt - SPIEGEL ONLINE |publisher=[[Spiegel.de]] |language=de |date=2012-07-11 |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> These solids do not float in air because the hollow spaces in them become filled with air. No lighter-than-air matrix or shell containing a hard vacuum has ever been constructed.
== See also == * [[Aerostat]] * [[Airship]] * [[Balloon (aircraft)]] * [[Buoyancy]] * [[Heavier than air]] * [[Hot air balloon]] * [[Vacuum balloon]] * [[Vacuum airship]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090217131144/http://www.floatograph.com/skydoc/ SkyDoc Aerostat resources] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040604033517/http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Lighter_than_air/LTA-OV.htm Lighter-than-air - An overview] *[http://www.airship-association.org/ Airship Association] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070623063501/http://www.heidas.de/pages/MainEng.html Steam Balloon Project] *[http://www.aerophile.com/ Helium balloons manufacturer]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lighter Than Air}} [[Category:Fluid mechanics]] [[Category:Atmosphere]]

The following is a list of notable companies in the [[petroleum industry]] that are engaged in [[petroleum]] exploration and production. The list is in alphabetical order by continent and then by country. This list does not include companies only involved in refining and marketing.

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
This '''list of prototype solar-powered cars''' comprises multiperson, relatively practical [[solar-powered vehicle|vehicle]]s powered completely or significantly by [[solar cell]]s ([[Solar panel|panels]] or [[Solar array|arrays]], mounted on the vehicle) which convert [[Solar energy|sunlight]] into [[electricity]] to drive [[Traction motor|electric motors]] while the vehicle is in motion and have a homologation for public streets.
== Australia ==
=== Sunswift V (eVe) === [[File:EVe's roof-view.jpg|thumb|right|The Sunswift V (eVe) with team]] The Sunswift V (aka "[[UNSW Sunswift#Sunswift V .28eVe.29 .282012 - current.29|eVe]]") from the [[University of New South Wales]] was built for the 2013 & 2015 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/19 |title=UNSW Solar Racing Team - Sunswift | World Solar Challenge 2013 |publisher=Worldsolarchallenge.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130913105948/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/19 |archivedate=2013-09-13 |df= }}</ref>
=== Solar Spirit 3 === The "Solar Spirit 3" with 3 seats was built by [[Technical and further education|TAFE South Australia]] for the 2011 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tafesa.edu.au/solar-car/solar-cars |title=Solar Cars |publisher=Tafe Sa |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref>
== Brazil ==
=== e.coTech Solar version === The "e.coTech" is a normal electric car developed by "HiTech Electric" and is sold only to small and medium-sized businesses. In 2017, the solar version of "e.coTech" was announced and presented to the public in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hitech-e.com.br/blog/veiculo-eletrico-com-recarga-fotovoltaica-aqui-brasil.html |title=Veículo elétrico com recarga fotovoltaica aqui no Brasil. |publisher=HiTech Electric |date=2018-02-23 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== Canada ==
=== Schulich Delta === The "Schulich Delta" from the [[University of Calgary]] was built for the 2013 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/23 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029184029/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/23 |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }}</ref>
== China ==
=== Cars without name === The handicraft enthusiast "Chen Shungui" developed 2 prototypes. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/auto/aktuell/sonne-im-tank-solarmobil-in-heimarbeit-a-726710.html |title=Sonne im Tank: Solarmobil in Heimarbeit - SPIEGEL ONLINE |publisher=Spiegel.de |date=2010-11-08 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref>
== Germany ==
=== Hochschule Bochum: Open World === [[File:Hochschule Bochum-Open World.jpg|thumb|right| University Bochum: Open World]] The solar vehicle was built in 2015 from the "Hochschule Bochum" to cross the desert of Tanami in Australia. Range with fully charged accumulator is 50 kilometers. The car have a solar roof with 160 Wp and in a box below the roof (not on the picture) 1943 Wp (!) solar panels for extension during driving breaks.
=== PowerCore SunCruiser === [[File:PowerCore SunCruiser.jpg|thumb|right|The "PowerCore SunCruiser"]] The "PowerCore SunCruiser" with 3 seats was built in 2013 by "Hochschule Bochum". <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hochschule-bochum.de/en/solarcar.html |title=SolarCar - SolarCar - Hochschule Bochum |publisher=Hochschule-bochum.de |date=2012-02-17 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref> Maximum Power created on his solar roof is 833 Wp. Car is equipped with 4 wheel hub electric engines. Participant on the [[World Solar Challenge]] 2013.
=== Sion === {{Main article|Sion (electric car)}}
[[File:Sono Sion 2017-08-18 1213.JPG|thumb|Der Sono Sion im Münchner Olympiastadion]] The Sion model from Sono Motors was presented to the public in July 2016. Two prototypes were financed by crowdfunding and were available for test drives in August 2017. The price will be EUR 16,000,- plus the battery you can rent or buy (<EUR 4.000, -). Pre-orders are available through the website<ref>[http://sonomotors.com/sion.html/ ''Sion by Sono Motors'']</ref> of Sono Motors. Delivery is scheduled to start in the 3rd quarter of 2019.
The car has 5 doors, an 80kW engine with a maximum speed of 140 km/h, is rechargeable with AC power (3.7 kW or 22 kW) and direct current (50 kW). The battery will have a realistic range of 250 km.
The solar cells (1.208 Wp) integrated into the car body charge the battery so that, in good sunshine, up to 30 km of additional range per day are possible.
It is possible to use the current of the battery in the Sion to operate electrical devices or to charge other electric cars.
The workshop manual for the Sion including the CAD data of all spare parts for 3D printers or CNC Milling will be public, so that reasonable repair costs are to be expected.
The owner of the vehicle can offer other people a power supply (power-sharing) or a ride-in (ridesharing) or rent his car (car sharing).
=== SolarWorld GT === The 2-seater "SolarWorld GT" was built 2011 by "Hochschule Bochum" with 2 wheel hub electric engines in the front wheels. After the participation at the 2011 [[World Solar Challenge]], the car and his team did the first full autarky world circumnavigation (10/2011-12/2012).<ref>[http://www.hochschule-bochum.de/en/solarcar/global-circumnavigation-20112.html Hochschule Bochum: Going 'Round the World? Sun powered!]</ref> This record was admitted by [[Guinness World Records]]. <ref>[http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/1000/longest-journey-by-solar-electric-vehicle Guinness World Records: Longest journey by solar electric vehicle]</ref> On the roof of the car are 3 m² solar cells and in the trunk additional 3 m² which are used during driving breaks. Maximum power creation of all solar cells is 1340Wp. More technical data can be found here:.<ref>[http://www.hochschule-bochum.de/en/solarcar/models/solarworld-gt.html Hochschule Bochum: SolarWorld GT|]</ref>
=== ThyssenKrupp SunRiser === [[File:ThyssenKrupp SunRiser.jpg|thumb|right|ThyssenKrupp SunRiser]] "The "PowerCore SunCruiser" with two seats was built by "Hochschule Bochum" for the 2015 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>[http://bosolarcar.de/ SolarCar Team Bochum (in German)]</ref> Maximum Power created on its 3 m² solar roof is 870 Wp. Car is equipped with 2 wheel hub electric engines and comfort electronics. Top speed is 120 km/h. Range with solar charging only is up to 600 kilometers per day. Range with fully charged accumulator (14,8 kWh) is up to 1100 kilometers.
== India ==
=== SolarMobil === The team [[SolarMobil Manipal|SolarMobil]] from the [[Manipal University]] built a prototype 2-seater solar passenger car called "SERVe" in 2015.
== Italy ==
=== P-Mob === <!--[[File:P-MOB.jpg|thumb|right|P-MOB]]--> With an EU - project led by Fiat (May 2010 - April 2013) a complete solar car with 3 seats was developed. This small car have four wheel drive. Range with solar charging only is 20 kilometers per day. Range with fully charged accumulator is 120 kilometers. Homologation and serial production is under investigation (as of September 2013).<ref>http://eeepro.shef.ac.uk/p-mob/index.html{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== Emilia 4 ===
Developed and built in Emilia Romagna in 2018 by the University of Bologna, the [https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Onda_solare Onda Solare] Association and several industrial partners, Emilia 4 is a 4.6 meter long, 1.8 meter wide and 1.2 meter high 4 seats vehicle. It is equipped with a 5 square meter photovoltaic roof, made of 362 silicon cells, with a nominal power of 1200W.<ref>https://fesr.regione.emilia-romagna.it/por-fesr/comunicazione/ioinvestoqui/materiali/onda-solare</ref>
== Japan == [[File:Kogakuin University OWL.jpeg|thumb|230px|Japan's [[Kogakuin University]]'s OWL car took 2nd place in the Cruiser class of the 2015 World Solar Challenge.]] === Kaiton II === The "KAITON II" from the "Goko High School" was built for the 2013 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/29 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130903153045/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/29 |archivedate=2013-09-03 |df= }}</ref>
=== OWL === "OWL" was built for the 2015 [[World Solar Challenge]] in the Cruiser class by [[Kogakuin University]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/35# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-01-13 |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160516012909/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/35# |archive-date=2016-05-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Monaco ==
=== Venturi Astrolab === [[File:VenturiConcept2.JPG|thumb|right|Venturi Astrolab]] [[Venturi Automobiles]] has built the open 2-seater "[[Venturi Astrolab|Astrolab]]" since 2006. With solar charging only, its range is 18 kilometers per day. Its range with the accumulator fully charged is 110 kilometers. It has a top speed of 120 km/h. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://en.venturi.fr/vehicles/venturi-range/astrolab/overview# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-11-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150423175630/http://en.venturi.fr/vehicles/venturi-range/astrolab/overview# |archive-date=2015-04-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[https://www.venturi.com/automotive-4/astrolab/ 'astrolab'] at venturi.com, Accessed 26 April 2018</ref>
=== Venturi Eclectic === <!--[[File:Venturi-eclectic-06.jpg|thumb|right|Eclectic]]--> [[File:VenturiConcept1.JPG|thumb|right|Venturi Eclectic]] [[Venturi Automobiles]] designed the flanking seating, open-sided 3-seater "[[Venturi Eclectic|Eclectic]]" as a prototype in 2006. Its range with solar charging only is 7 kilometers per day. Fully charged, its accumulator gives a range of 50 kilometers. The car has a top speed 50 km/h. Its price was 'middle of the road' as announced, but serial production never started. There is also a small electric car with the name "Eclectic 2.0" from the same company. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.venturi.fr/vehicles/venturi-range/eclectic-concept/overview |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131130075630/http://en.venturi.fr/vehicles/venturi-range/eclectic-concept/overview |archivedate=2013-11-30 |df= }}</ref>
== The Netherlands ==
=== Stella ===
The 4-seater "[[Stella (solar vehicles)|Stella]]" was built for the 2013 [[World Solar Challenge]] by [[Eindhoven University]].<ref>http://www.tue.nl/en/university/news-and-press/news/student-team-unveils-worlds-first-solar-powered-family-car/</ref> It was the winner in its class, and went on to win the [[crunchies]] award.<ref>http://www.tue.nl/en/university/news-and-press/news/06-02-2015-solar-team-eindhoven-wins-crunchie-in-san-francisco/</ref>
=== Stella Lux === The 4-seater [[Stella (solar vehicles)#Stella Lux|"Stella Lux"]] was built as successor of Stella for the 2015 [[World Solar Challenge]] by [[Eindhoven University]].<ref>http://www.solarteameindhoven.nl/stella-lux/</ref> It was the winner in its class again. With a top speed of 125 km/h and a European range of 1000 kilometers it is a substantial achievement with respect to common electric vehicles.
=== Stella Vie === In 2017 the Eindhoven team have built a new car for the World Solar Challenge, called Stella Vie, featuring five instead of four seats. By its introduction, this car was the most efficient family car ever built. More efficient than its predecessors due to its light weight and aerodynamic form and efficient enough to win the Cruiser Class of the World Solar Challenge for the third consecutive time with a big lead on the competition.
=== Twente One ===
[[File:Autopresentatie.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Twente One]] [[File:TwenteOnevleugel.png|right|thumb|chassis of Twente One]] [[File:AandrijvingTwenteOne.png|right|thumb|Driving wheel of Twente One]]
The '''Twente One''' is the second [[Solar car racing|solar car]] developed by the [[Twente University|University of Twente]] and [[Saxion|Saxion University]] (at [[Enschede]], [[Deventer]] and [[Apeldoorn]]) in 2007, and succeeds the [[SolUTra]]. It was designed to participate in the 2007 [[World Solar Challenge]].
Its main innovations were a pivoting solar screen that follows the angle of the sun, and a system of [[fresnel lens]]es that focus the sunlight onto a solar panel with a system to adjust the panel so that the maximum amount of light from the lenses shines on the individual [[solar cell]]s.
The Twente One came in on the fifth place in the 2007 World solar Challenge.
==== Specifications ==== {|cellspacing=0 cellpadding="5px" border=1 |Length||5000mm |- |Width||1800mm |- |Height||1400mm |- |Weight (excluding Driver)||<230 kg |- |Number of wheels ||3 |- |Characteristics||Pivoting solar panel & lens system with Fresnel lenses and movable solar cells |- |Top-speed||120 km/h |- |Solar cells||2073 Gallium-Arsenide Triple Junction, area 6m² |- |Efficiency of solar cells||>27% |- |Motor||In-Wheel Direct Drive Electric Motor NGM/CSIRO 95%-99% |- |Battery||30 kg Lithium Polymer |- |Control||Steering wheel from aluminium tube with a width like a CD-box, and with quick-release |- |Bodywork||Carbon fibre sandwich construction |- |Chassis||Box-construction from aluminium plate-work, connected through high quality aluminium milled parts, roller-bars from chrome-molybdenum-steel |- |Fore-wheel suspension||Double A-arm construction from chrome-molybdenum-steel, horizontal racing shock absorbers, lightweight aluminium rims, ceramic bearings |- |Hind-wheel suspension||Trailing-arm construction of chrome-molybdenum-steel |- |Tires||Bridgestone/Maxxis radial 14 inch (slicks) |- |Brakes||Brake-discs with aerospace braking-hoses in the front, regenerative braking in the back |- |Rolling friction||one tenth that of a normal car |- |Air friction||one fifth that of a normal car |- |Telemetry||Wireless connection with following car, car transmits about 200 measuring signals |- |Crew||One team-member |}
== New Zealand ==
=== UltraCommuter === The "UltraCommuter" from the [[University of Waikato]] was built for the 2013 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/52 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118014842/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/52 |archivedate=2014-01-18 |df= }}</ref>
== Pakistan ==
=== ECO1, ECO1GL and ECO3GL === ECO1, ECO1GL and ECO3GL are built by a technology enthusiast and entrepreneur Muhammad Aslam Azaad. Built in March 2014. <!--<ref>[http://www.economia.com.pk/images/vwt.pdf/]</ref>-->
== Slovenia ==
=== Metron 7 === A Mazda 5 was converted to an electric car named Metron 7 by Andrej Pecjak and his Metron team and in 2014 permitted for public use. Range with solar charging (160 Watt) is a few kilometers per day. Range with fully charged accumulator is 824 ! kilometers, proved from Berlin to Karlsruhe and through cities with average speed 72 km/h in June 2016.<ref>http://eauto.si/en/metron7-2/</ref>
=== Superpiki === The project "Yuneec & Metron" convert a Smart Roadster to an electric car with 80 Wp solar panel in 2011. Range with solar charging only is a few kilometers per day. Range with fully charged accumulator is 160 kilometers. <ref>http://www.ad-pecjak.si/ECO/Smart/Superpiki.htm</ref>
== Switzerland ==
=== Icare === The project "Icare" build a [[Twike]] (Hybrid: muscular strength + electric engine) with an additional solar trailer (1800 Wp) and a small wind generator (diameter 1,8 m). With that vehicle they circumnavigate the world in 2010/11. <ref>http://planetsave.com/2011/08/30/solar-powered-3-wheeler-icare-twike-top-green-living-stories/</ref>
=== Solar Taxi === [[File:Solartaxi.jpg|thumb|right|Palmer in his "Solartaxi"]] This vehicle circumnavigate the world 2007/08 with "Lois Palmer" as driver. Energy was delivered to 50% from the solar trailer (6 m²) and to 50% from the power grid (which was indirectly produced by a solar installation in Switzerland). Power consumption: 8 kWh / 100 km. <ref>[http://www.solartaxi.com/ Solartaxi]</ref>
== Taiwan ==
=== Apollo Solar Cruiser Car === The "Apollo Solar Car Team" from [[National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences]] build a solar car for the 2013 [[World Solar Challenge]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/27 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140614173956/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/27 |archivedate=2014-06-14 |df= }}</ref>
== USA ==
=== Daedalus === "Daedalus" of the [[University of Minnesota Solar Vehicle Project|University of Minnesota]] was built in 2013 for the [[World Solar Challenge#2013|World Solar Challenge]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/47 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130913105919/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/47 |archivedate=2013-09-13 |df= }}</ref> It is currently on display at the [[PTC (software company)|PTC]] world headquarters in [[Boston|Boston, MA]].
=== Eos === "Eos" of the [[University of Minnesota Solar Vehicle Project|University of Minnesota]] was built in 2015 for the [[World Solar Challenge#2015|World Solar Challenge]] and the 2016 [[American Solar Challenge#2016|American Solar Challenge]]. It is the only active multi-occupant solar car in the United States. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/47 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130913105919/http://www.worldsolarchallenge.org/team/view/47 |archivedate=2013-09-13 |df= }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Lists of cars|Solar cars (with homologation)]] [[Category:Photovoltaics|*]] [[Category:Solar-powered vehicles|*]]
